conclusion: P-V diagram shows a Stirling cycle with states A, B, C, and D
Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal
We need to determine if the velocity distribution of gas molecules changes during D→A
A→B: Isothermal expansion (stated in the problem)
B→C: Based on the curve shape, this appears to be isochoric cooling
C→D: Isothermal compression (stated in the problem)
D→A: Based on the curve shape, this appears to be isochoric heating

premise: The D→A path shows increasing pressure at constant volume, which indicates an isochoric (constant volume) heating process.
conclusion: During an isochoric process in an ideal gas: Volume is constant; If pressure increases, temperature must increase (from the ideal gas law: P = nRT/V); Since P increases from D to A at constant V, temperature must increase
The Maxwell-Boltzmann velocity distribution of gas molecules depends primarily on temperature. The probability density function is given by: f(v) = 4π (m/2π kT)^(3/2) v^2 e^(-mv^2/2kT)
Where: m is the mass of a molecule; k is Boltzmann's constant; T is the absolute temperature; v is the velocity

premise: During an isochoric process in an ideal gas: Volume is constant; If pressure increases, temperature must increase (from the ideal gas law: P = nRT/V); Since P increases from D to A at constant V, temperature must increase
conclusion: When temperature increases: The peak of the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution shifts to higher velocities; The distribution becomes broader; The average molecular velocity increases; The distribution curve changes its shape

premise: When temperature increases: The peak of the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution shifts to higher velocities; The distribution becomes broader; The average molecular velocity increases; The distribution curve changes its shape
conclusion: Yes, the velocity distribution curve of the gas molecules changes during the D→A process. Since this is an isochoric heating process where temperature increases, the Maxwell-Boltzmann velocity distribution will shift toward higher velocities, become broader, and have a higher average velocity. The fundamental shape of the distribution curve changes as the temperature increases from state D to state A.
